Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Thor—son of Odin, god of thunder, 
and protector of mankind— struggled mightily against his greatest
challenge yet: opening a bag of food. It’d all started when Thor, along with his fleet-footed human servant
Thjalfi and Loki, the trickster god, set out on a journey to Jotunheim, 
land of the giants. Along the way, they’d met 
a giant named Skrymir, who offered to accompany them and
even carry their provisions in his bag. But when they made camp,
Skrymir dozed off and Thor couldn’t untie the sack. Frustrated and hungry, Thor tried 
to wake the giant three times by striking his head with his hammer 
Mjolnir as hard as he could. But each time, Skrymir thought 
it was only a falling acorn and went back to sleep. The next morning, Skrymir departed and eventually, the travelers reached 
a massive fortress called Utgard. Inside the long hall, 
they met the king of giants, Utgard-Loki, who greeted his guests with a challenge: each of them was to prove they were 
the best at some particular skill. Loki went first, declaring himself 
the world’s fastest eater. To test him, the king summoned 
his servant Logi and the two were placed at either 
end of a long trough stuffed with food. Loki ate his way inward 
with blinding speed. But when the contestants 
met in the center, Loki saw that his adversary 
had not only eaten just as much food, but also the bones 
and even the trough itself. Next was Thjalfi, who could 
outrun anything in the wild. The king summoned an ethereal-looking 
giant named Hugi, who outraced Thjalfi easily. But the boy would not give up 
and demanded a rematch. This time, Thjalfi finished close behind and the king admitted he’d never 
seen a human run so fast. Thjalfi tried a third time, 
running like his life depended on it, but Hugi was even faster than before. Finally, it was Thor’s turn. The king offered him a drinking horn, saying all his men 
could drain it in two gulps. Thor raised it to his lips and drank the surprisingly 
cold and salty mead in the longest gulp he could muster. Then a second. Then a third. But the level of the mead 
in the horn was only slightly lowered. To test Thor’s renowned strength, the king
offered a seemingly easy challenge: lift his pet cat off the ground. But this cat was as tall as Thor. Every time he tried to lift it, 
it arched its back, and straining with all his godly might, 
he only managed to lift one paw. Enraged, Thor demanded 
to wrestle any of the giants. The king summoned 
the giants’ old nursemaid, Elli. Though the woman looked frail, 
Thor couldn’t overpower her and grew weaker the longer he struggled,
until he was brought to one knee. The three companions prepared 
to leave, disappointed and humbled. But as the king escorted them out, he revealed that nothing in the castle 
had been what it seemed. Loki lost the eating contest because 
his opponent Logi was wildfire itself, devouring everything in its path. Thjalfi couldn’t outrun Hugi because
Hugi was the embodiment of thought, always faster than action. And even Thor couldn’t defeat Elli, 
or old age, which weakens everyone eventually. As for the other challenges, 
they had also been illusions. The drinking horn 
was filled with the ocean, and Thor had drained
enough to cause the tides. The cat was the serpent 
that encircles the world, and Thor’s efforts shifted the earth. And Skrymir had been 
Utgard-Loki in disguise, deflecting Thor’s hammer-blows to form
valleys in the surrounding mountains. The giant congratulated 
them on their prowess, which so frightened him he would 
never allow them in his land again. Thor and his companions failed 
the challenges presented to them. But in trying to achieve the impossible, they’d pushed themselves 
harder than ever before and changed the world 
in ways no one had expected.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Thor is known as _______.
Options: A. The protector of mankind, B. The trickster god, C. The god of thunder, D. The protector of mankind and the god of thunder, E. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who accompanied Thor on his journey to Jotunheim? Options: A. Odin and Loki, B. Thjalfi and Loki, C. Odin and Thjalfi, D. Heimdall and Loki Correct Option: B
Question 2: Why did Skrymir think Thor struck his head with Mjolnir? Options: A. He thought Thor was trying to wake him up for dinner, B. He thought it was a falling acorn, C. He thought it was an earthquake, D. He thought it was a wild animal Correct Option: B
Question 3: What challenge did Loki participate in at Utgard? Options: A. A wrestling match, B. An eating contest, C. A drinking competition, D. A running contest Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the true nature of Logi, Loki's opponent in the eating contest? Options: A. A giant with a huge appetite, B. A magical creature with the ability to eat fast, C. Wildfire itself, devouring everything in its path, D. A skilled cook who prepared the food Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was the outcome of Thjalfi's running contests against Hugi? Options: A. Thjalfi won all three contests, B. Thjalfi lost all three contests, C. Thjalfi won one contest and lost two, D. Thjalfi lost the first contest, finished close behind in the second, and lost the third Correct Option: D
Question 6: What was the true nature of the challenges presented to Thor and his companions at Utgard? Options: A. They were genuine tests of strength and skill, B. They were illusions designed to humiliate the visitors, C. They were games played by the giants for entertainment, D. They were a combination of physical and mental challenges Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the true nature of the drinking horn presented to Thor? Options: A. A magical horn that could never be emptied, B. A horn filled with a special liquid that granted strength, C. A horn filled with the ocean, and Thor's efforts caused the tides, D. A horn made of a material that was impossible to lift Correct Option: C
Question 8: What lesson can be learned from Thor and his companions' experiences at Utgard? Options: A. That it's impossible to win against giants, B. That illusions can be powerful tools for deception, C. That trying to achieve the impossible can lead to unexpected results and growth, D. That physical strength is the most important quality for success Correct Option: C
Question 9: How did Thor's efforts to lift the cat affect the world? Options: A. They caused a great storm, B. They created a massive earthquake, C. They shifted the earth, D. They had no effect on the world Correct Option: C
Question 10: Why did Utgard-Loki congratulate Thor and his companions despite their failures? Options: A. Because they had entertained him with their efforts, B. Because they had proven themselves to be worthy opponents, C. Because their prowess had frightened him, and he would never allow them in his land again, D. Because they had passed a secret test of character Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Thor—son of Odin, god of thunder, 
and protector of mankind— struggled mightily against his greatest
challenge yet: opening a bag of food. It’d all started when Thor, along with his fleet-footed human servant
Thjalfi and Loki, the trickster god, set out on a journey to Jotunheim, 
land of the giants. Along the way, they’d met 
a giant named Skrymir, who offered to accompany them and
even carry their provisions in his bag. But when they made camp,
Skrymir dozed off and Thor couldn’t untie the sack. Frustrated and hungry, Thor tried 
to wake the giant three times by striking his head with his hammer 
Mjolnir as hard as he could. But each time, Skrymir thought 
it was only a falling acorn and went back to sleep. The next morning, Skrymir departed and eventually, the travelers reached 
a massive fortress called Utgard. Inside the long hall, 
they met the king of giants, Utgard-Loki, who greeted his guests with a challenge: each of them was to prove they were 
the best at some particular skill. Loki went first, declaring himself 
the world’s fastest eater. To test him, the king summoned 
his servant Logi and the two were placed at either 
end of a long trough stuffed with food. Loki ate his way inward 
with blinding speed. But when the contestants 
met in the center, Loki saw that his adversary 
had not only eaten just as much food, but also the bones 
and even the trough itself. Next was Thjalfi, who could 
outrun anything in the wild. The king summoned an ethereal-looking 
giant named Hugi, who outraced Thjalfi easily. But the boy would not give up 
and demanded a rematch. This time, Thjalfi finished close behind and the king admitted he’d never 
seen a human run so fast. Thjalfi tried a third time, 
running like his life depended on it, but Hugi was even faster than before. Finally, it was Thor’s turn. The king offered him a drinking horn, saying all his men 
could drain it in two gulps. Thor raised it to his lips and drank the surprisingly 
cold and salty mead in the longest gulp he could muster. Then a second. Then a third. But the level of the mead 
in the horn was only slightly lowered. To test Thor’s renowned strength, the king
offered a seemingly easy challenge: lift his pet cat off the ground. But this cat was as tall as Thor. Every time he tried to lift it, 
it arched its back, and straining with all his godly might, 
he only managed to lift one paw. Enraged, Thor demanded 
to wrestle any of the giants. The king summoned 
the giants’ old nursemaid, Elli. Though the woman looked frail, 
Thor couldn’t overpower her and grew weaker the longer he struggled,
until he was brought to one knee. The three companions prepared 
to leave, disappointed and humbled. But as the king escorted them out, he revealed that nothing in the castle 
had been what it seemed. Loki lost the eating contest because 
his opponent Logi was wildfire itself, devouring everything in its path. Thjalfi couldn’t outrun Hugi because
Hugi was the embodiment of thought, always faster than action. And even Thor couldn’t defeat Elli, 
or old age, which weakens everyone eventually. As for the other challenges, 
they had also been illusions. The drinking horn 
was filled with the ocean, and Thor had drained
enough to cause the tides. The cat was the serpent 
that encircles the world, and Thor’s efforts shifted the earth. And Skrymir had been 
Utgard-Loki in disguise, deflecting Thor’s hammer-blows to form
valleys in the surrounding mountains. The giant congratulated 
them on their prowess, which so frightened him he would 
never allow them in his land again. Thor and his companions failed 
the challenges presented to them. But in trying to achieve the impossible, they’d pushed themselves 
harder than ever before and changed the world 
in ways no one had expected.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Thor is known as _______.
Options: A. The protector of mankind, B. The trickster god, C. The god of thunder, D. The protector of mankind and the god of thunder, E. All of the above
Correct Option: D

That physical strength is the most important quality for success Correct Option: C

in ways no one had expected.

running like his life depended on it, but Hugi was even faster than before. Finally, it was Thor’s turn. The king offered him a drinking horn, saying all his men 
could drain it in two gulps. Thor raised it to his lips and drank the surprisingly 
cold and salty mead in the longest gulp he could muster. Then a second. Then a third. But the level of the mead 
in the horn was only slightly lowered. To test Thor’s renowned strength, the king
offered a seemingly easy challenge: lift his pet cat off the ground. But this cat was as tall as Thor. Every time he tried to lift it, 
it arched its back, and straining with all his godly might, 
he only managed to lift one paw. Enraged, Thor demanded 
to wrestle any of the giants. The king summoned 
the giants’ old nursemaid, Elli. Though the woman looked frail, 
Thor couldn’t overpower her and grew weaker the longer he struggled,
until he was brought to one knee. The three companions prepared 
to leave, disappointed and humbled. But as the king escorted them out, he revealed that nothing in the castle 
had been what it seemed. Loki lost the eating contest because 
his opponent Logi was wildfire itself, devouring everything in its path. Thjalfi couldn’t outrun Hugi because
Hugi was the embodiment of thought, always faster than action. And even Thor couldn’t defeat Elli, 
or old age, which weakens everyone eventually. As for the other challenges, 
they had also been illusions. The drinking horn 
was filled with the ocean, and Thor had drained
enough to cause the tides. The cat was the serpent 
that encircles the world, and Thor’s efforts shifted the earth. And Skrymir had been 
Utgard-Loki in disguise, deflecting Thor’s hammer-blows to form
valleys in the surrounding mountains. The giant congratulated 
them on their prowess, which so frightened him he would 
never allow them in his land again. Thor and his companions failed 
the challenges presented to them. But in trying to achieve the impossible, they’d pushed themselves 
harder than ever before and changed the world 
in ways no one had expected.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many times did Thjalfi try to win the challenge he was presented with?
Options: A. 1, B. 2, C. 3, D. 4
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who accompanied Thor on his journey to Jotunheim? Options: A. Odin and Loki, B. Thjalfi and Loki, C. Odin and Thjalfi, D. Heimdall and Loki Correct Option: B
Question 2: Why did Skrymir think Thor struck his head with Mjolnir? Options: A. He thought Thor was trying to wake him up for dinner, B. He thought it was a falling acorn, C. He thought it was an earthquake, D. He thought it was a wild animal Correct Option: B
Question 3: What challenge did Loki participate in at Utgard? Options: A. A wrestling match, B. An eating contest, C. A drinking competition, D. A running contest Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the true nature of Logi, Loki's opponent in the eating contest? Options: A. A giant with a huge appetite, B. A magical creature with the ability to eat fast, C. Wildfire itself, devouring everything in its path, D. A skilled cook who prepared the food Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was the outcome of Thjalfi's running contests against Hugi? Options: A. Thjalfi won all three contests, B. Thjalfi lost all three contests, C. Thjalfi won one contest and lost two, D. Thjalfi lost the first contest, finished close behind in the second, and lost the third Correct Option: D
Question 6: What was the true nature of the challenges presented to Thor and his companions at Utgard? Options: A. They were genuine tests of strength and skill, B. They were illusions designed to humiliate the visitors, C. They were games played by the giants for entertainment, D. They were a combination of physical and mental challenges Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the true nature of the drinking horn presented to Thor? Options: A. A magical horn that could never be emptied, B. A horn filled with a special liquid that granted strength, C. A horn filled with the ocean, and Thor's efforts caused the tides, D. A horn made of a material that was impossible to lift Correct Option: C
Question 8: What lesson can be learned from Thor and his companions' experiences at Utgard? Options: A. That it's impossible to win against giants, B. That illusions can be powerful tools for deception, C. That trying to achieve the impossible can lead to unexpected results and growth, D. That physical strength is the most important quality for success Correct Option: C
Question 9: How did Thor's efforts to lift the cat affect the world? Options: A. They caused a great storm, B. They created a massive earthquake, C. They shifted the earth, D. They had no effect on the world Correct Option: C
Question 10: Why did Utgard-Loki congratulate Thor and his companions despite their failures? Options: A. Because they had entertained him with their efforts, B. Because they had proven themselves to be worthy opponents, C. Because their prowess had frightened him, and he would never allow them in his land again, D. Because they had passed a secret test of character Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 6
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Thor—son of Odin, god of thunder, 
and protector of mankind— struggled mightily against his greatest
challenge yet: opening a bag of food. It’d all started when Thor, along with his fleet-footed human servant
Thjalfi and Loki, the trickster god, set out on a journey to Jotunheim, 
land of the giants. Along the way, they’d met 
a giant named Skrymir, who offered to accompany them and
even carry their provisions in his bag. But when they made camp,
Skrymir dozed off and Thor couldn’t untie the sack. Frustrated and hungry, Thor tried 
to wake the giant three times by striking his head with his hammer 
Mjolnir as hard as he could. But each time, Skrymir thought 
it was only a falling acorn and went back to sleep. The next morning, Skrymir departed and eventually, the travelers reached 
a massive fortress called Utgard. Inside the long hall, 
they met the king of giants, Utgard-Loki, who greeted his guests with a challenge: each of them was to prove they were 
the best at some particular skill. Loki went first, declaring himself 
the world’s fastest eater. To test him, the king summoned 
his servant Logi and the two were placed at either 
end of a long trough stuffed with food. Loki ate his way inward 
with blinding speed. But when the contestants 
met in the center, Loki saw that his adversary 
had not only eaten just as much food, but also the bones 
and even the trough itself. Next was Thjalfi, who could 
outrun anything in the wild. The king summoned an ethereal-looking 
giant named Hugi, who outraced Thjalfi easily. But the boy would not give up 
and demanded a rematch. This time, Thjalfi finished close behind and the king admitted he’d never 
seen a human run so fast. Thjalfi tried a third time, 
running like his life depended on it, but Hugi was even faster than before. Finally, it was Thor’s turn. The king offered him a drinking horn, saying all his men 
could drain it in two gulps. Thor raised it to his lips and drank the surprisingly 
cold and salty mead in the longest gulp he could muster. Then a second. Then a third. But the level of the mead 
in the horn was only slightly lowered. To test Thor’s renowned strength, the king
offered a seemingly easy challenge: lift his pet cat off the ground. But this cat was as tall as Thor. Every time he tried to lift it, 
it arched its back, and straining with all his godly might, 
he only managed to lift one paw. Enraged, Thor demanded 
to wrestle any of the giants. The king summoned 
the giants’ old nursemaid, Elli. Though the woman looked frail, 
Thor couldn’t overpower her and grew weaker the longer he struggled,
until he was brought to one knee. The three companions prepared 
to leave, disappointed and humbled. But as the king escorted them out, he revealed that nothing in the castle 
had been what it seemed. Loki lost the eating contest because 
his opponent Logi was wildfire itself, devouring everything in its path. Thjalfi couldn’t outrun Hugi because
Hugi was the embodiment of thought, always faster than action. And even Thor couldn’t defeat Elli, 
or old age, which weakens everyone eventually. As for the other challenges, 
they had also been illusions. The drinking horn 
was filled with the ocean, and Thor had drained
enough to cause the tides. The cat was the serpent 
that encircles the world, and Thor’s efforts shifted the earth. And Skrymir had been 
Utgard-Loki in disguise, deflecting Thor’s hammer-blows to form
valleys in the surrounding mountains. The giant congratulated 
them on their prowess, which so frightened him he would 
never allow them in his land again. Thor and his companions failed 
the challenges presented to them. But in trying to achieve the impossible, they’d pushed themselves 
harder than ever before and changed the world 
in ways no one had expected.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The drinking horn was filled with the ocean. Thor drank enough of it to cause _______.
Options: A. A tsunami, B. The tides, C. A drought, D. Boats to capsize
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It was the Western Hemisphere’s 
largest empire ever, with a population 
of nearly 10 million subjects. Over an area of more 
than 900,000 square kilometers, its people built massive 
administrative centers, temples, and extensive road 
and canal systems. They did so in an inhospitable, 
extreme terrain, all without the use of wheels, 
horses, iron, or even written language. Yet within 100 years of its rise 
in the fifteenth century, the Inca Empire would be no more. According to legend, the ancestors of the Inca rulers 
were created by the sun god Inti, and they emerged
from a cave called Tambo Toco. Leading four brothers 
and four sisters was Ayar Manco, who carried a golden staff 
with instructions to find the place where 
it would sink into the ground, showing fertile soil. After many adventures 
and extensive searching, Ayar Manco and his siblings 
reached the Cuzco Valley, where the staff pierced the ground. After fighting off the fierce 
local native population, they founded their capital, and Ayar Manco became Manco Capac, 
the first Sapa Inca, or king of the Incas. Archaeological evidence suggests that the Incas first settled 
in this valley around 1200 CE. They remained a small kingdom until 1438, when they were nearly overrun 
by the neighboring Chanka tribe. The Inca king at this time, Viracocha, 
and his designated heir fled in fear, but one of his other sons remained and successfully rallied 
the city’s defenses. For his military skill, he became 
the ninth Inca ruler, assuming the name of Pachacuti, 
or "Cataclysm." Pachacuti expanded Inca rule 
throughout the Andes mountains, transforming the kingdom into 
an empire through extensive reforms. The empire’s territory was reorganized 
as Tahuantinsuyu, or "four quarters," with four divisions ruled 
by governors reporting to the king. Although the Inca had no writing, they used a complex system 
of knotted strings called quipu to record numbers 
and perhaps other information. A decimal-based bureaucracy 
enabled systematic and efficient taxation 
of the empire’s subjects. In return, the empire provided security, 
infrastructure, and sustenance, with great storehouses containing 
necessities to be used when needed. Great terraces and irrigation works 
were built and various crops were grown in 
at different altitudes to be transported all over the empire. And it was during Pachacuti’s reign that the famous estate 
of Machu Picchu was constructed. Pachacuti’s son Topa Inca continued 
the empire’s military expansion, and he eventually became ruler
in 1471 CE. By the end of his reign, the empire 
covered much of western South America. Topa’s son Huayna Capac 
succeeded him in 1493. But the new ruler’s distant military 
campaigns strained the social fabric. And in 1524, Huayna Capac 
was stricken by fever. Spanish conquistadors had arrived 
in the Caribbean some time before, bringing diseases to which 
the native peoples had no resistance. Millions died in the outbreak, including Huayna Capac
and his designated heir. The vacant throne ignited a civil war
between two of the surviving brothers, Atahualpa and Huascar, greatly weakening the empire. In 1532, after finally winning 
the Inca civil war, Atahualpa and his army 
encountered the European invaders. Although greatly outnumbered, Francisco Pizarro 
and his small group of conquistadors stunned the king’s much larger force 
with guns and horses, neither of which they had seen before. Atahualpa was taken captive 
and killed about a year later. The Spanish conquerors 
were awed by the capital of Cuzco. Pizarro described it as so beautiful that
“it would be remarkable even in Spain.” Though the capital had fallen and the native population had been
destroyed by civil war and disease, some Incas fell back to 
a new capital at Vilcabamba and resisted for the next 40 years. But by 1572, the Spaniards had destroyed 
all remaining resistance along with much of the Incas’ physical 
and cultural legacy. Thus, the great Inca empire fell 
even faster than it had risen.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Who was the first Inca ruler?
Options: A. Pachacuti, B. Topa Inca, C. Atahualpa, D. Manco Capac
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the approximate population of the Inca Empire at its peak? Options: A. 1 million, B. 5 million, C. 10 million, D. 20 million Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to legend, who created the ancestors of the Inca rulers? Options: A. The sun god Inti, B. The moon goddess Mama Quilla, C. The earth goddess Pachamama, D. The thunder god Viracocha Correct Option: A
Question 3: What was the name of the system used by the Incas to record numbers and information? Options: A. Quipu, B. Tahuantinsuyu, C. Machu Picchu, D. Cuzco Correct Option: A
Question 4: How did the Incas organize their empire's territory? Options: A. Into two divisions, with two governors reporting to the king, B. Into four divisions, with four governors reporting to the king, C. Into six divisions, with six governors reporting to the king, D. Into eight divisions, with eight governors reporting to the king Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the primary factor that led to the decline of the Inca Empire? Options: A. Civil war between Atahualpa and Huascar, B. The arrival of Spanish conquistadors, C. The spread of diseases brought by European invaders, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 6: How did the Incas adapt to the challenging terrain of the Andes mountains? Options: A. By building extensive road and canal systems, B. By using wheels and horses for transportation, C. By developing a system of writing, D. By abandoning their settlements and moving to lower elevations Correct Option: A
Question 7: What was the name of the estate constructed during Pachacuti's reign? Options: A. Machu Picchu, B. Cuzco, C. Vilcabamba, D. Tambo Toco Correct Option: A
Question 8: How did the Spanish conquistadors gain an advantage over the Inca army? Options: A. By using guerrilla warfare tactics, B. By forming alliances with other native tribes, C. By using guns and horses, which the Incas had not seen before, D. By outnumbering the Inca army Correct Option: C
Question 9: What was the outcome of the civil war between Atahualpa and Huascar? Options: A. Atahualpa emerged victorious and united the empire, B. Huascar emerged victorious and united the empire, C. The civil war weakened the empire, making it vulnerable to Spanish conquest, D. The civil war led to the rise of a new Inca ruler Correct Option: C
Question 10: What was the ultimate fate of the Inca Empire? Options: A. It was absorbed into the Spanish Empire and became a vassal state, B. It was destroyed by the Spanish conquistadors, with its physical and cultural legacy largely lost, C. It was able to resist Spanish conquest and maintain its independence, D. It was divided into smaller kingdoms, each ruled by a different Inca leader Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not an exact match, but Question 2 is the closest in terms of question intent and content.

However, since the question is asking about the first Inca ruler, I would expect a generated MCQ with options that include the answer "Manco Capac". Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ exactly.

If I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the available options, I would say that none of the generated MCQs are a good match. But if I had to pick one, I would say Question 2 is the closest, although it's not a good match.

But since the question is asking about the first Inca ruler, I will say that there is no matching generated MCQ.

 Nevertheless,  I will provide the index of the generated MCQ that is talking about the Inca rulers' ancestors, which is:

 Question 2

all remaining resistance along with much of the Incas’ physical 
and cultural legacy. Thus, the great Inca empire fell 
even faster than it had risen.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

largest empire ever, with a population 
of nearly 10 million subjects. Over an area of more 
than 900,000 square kilometers, its people built massive 
administrative centers, temples, and extensive road 
and canal systems. They did so in an inhospitable, 
extreme terrain, all without the use of wheels, 
horses, iron, or even written language. Yet within 100 years of its rise 
in the fifteenth century, the Inca Empire would be no more. According to legend, the ancestors of the Inca rulers 
were created by the sun god Inti, and they emerged
from a cave called Tambo Toco. Leading four brothers 
and four sisters was Ayar Manco, who carried a golden staff 
with instructions to find the place where 
it would sink into the ground, showing fertile soil. After many adventures 
and extensive searching, Ayar Manco and his siblings 
reached the Cuzco Valley, where the staff pierced the ground. After fighting off the fierce 
local native population, they founded their capital, and Ayar Manco became Manco Capac, 
the first Sapa Inca, or king of the Incas. Archaeological evidence suggests that the Incas first settled 
in this valley around 1200 CE. They remained a small kingdom until 1438, when they were nearly overrun 
by the neighboring Chanka tribe. The Inca king at this time, Viracocha, 
and his designated heir fled in fear, but one of his other sons remained and successfully rallied 
the city’s defenses. For his military skill, he became 
the ninth Inca ruler, assuming the name of Pachacuti, 
or "Cataclysm." Pachacuti expanded Inca rule 
throughout the Andes mountains, transforming the kingdom into 
an empire through extensive reforms. The empire’s territory was reorganized 
as Tahuantinsuyu, or "four quarters," with four divisions ruled 
by governors reporting to the king. Although the Inca had no writing, they used a complex system 
of knotted strings called quipu to record numbers 
and perhaps other information. A decimal-based bureaucracy 
enabled systematic and efficient taxation 
of the empire’s subjects. In return, the empire provided security, 
infrastructure, and sustenance, with great storehouses containing 
necessities to be used when needed. Great terraces and irrigation works 
were built and various crops were grown in 
at different altitudes to be transported all over the empire. And it was during Pachacuti’s reign that the famous estate 
of Machu Picchu was constructed. Pachacuti’s son Topa Inca continued 
the empire’s military expansion, and he eventually became ruler
in 1471 CE. By the end of his reign, the empire 
covered much of western South America. Topa’s son Huayna Capac 
succeeded him in 1493. But the new ruler’s distant military 
campaigns strained the social fabric. And in 1524, Huayna Capac 
was stricken by fever. Spanish conquistadors had arrived 
in the Caribbean some time before, bringing diseases to which 
the native peoples had no resistance. Millions died in the outbreak, including Huayna Capac
and his designated heir. The vacant throne ignited a civil war
between two of the surviving brothers, Atahualpa and Huascar, greatly weakening the empire. In 1532, after finally winning 
the Inca civil war, Atahualpa and his army 
encountered the European invaders. Although greatly outnumbered, Francisco Pizarro 
and his small group of conquistadors stunned the king’s much larger force 
with guns and horses, neither of which they had seen before. Atahualpa was taken captive 
and killed about a year later. The Spanish conquerors 
were awed by the capital of Cuzco. Pizarro described it as so beautiful that
“it would be remarkable even in Spain.” Though the capital had fallen and the native population had been
destroyed by civil war and disease, some Incas fell back to 
a new capital at Vilcabamba and resisted for the next 40 years. But by 1572, the Spaniards had destroyed 
all remaining resistance along with much of the Incas’ physical 
and cultural legacy. Thus, the great Inca empire fell 
even faster than it had risen.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The Inca Empire was divided into ____ major parts.
Options: A. 2, B. 8, C. 4, D. 6
Correct Option: C

The civil war led to the rise of a new Inca ruler Correct Option: C

It was destroyed by the Spanish conquistadors, with its physical and cultural legacy largely lost, C. It was able to resist Spanish conquest and maintain its independence, D. It was divided into smaller kingdoms, each ruled by a different Inca leader Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It was the Western Hemisphere’s 
largest empire ever, with a population 
of nearly 10 million subjects. Over an area of more 
than 900,000 square kilometers, its people built massive 
administrative centers, temples, and extensive road 
and canal systems. They did so in an inhospitable, 
extreme terrain, all without the use of wheels, 
horses, iron, or even written language. Yet within 100 years of its rise 
in the fifteenth century, the Inca Empire would be no more. According to legend, the ancestors of the Inca rulers 
were created by the sun god Inti, and they emerged
from a cave called Tambo Toco. Leading four brothers 
and four sisters was Ayar Manco, who carried a golden staff 
with instructions to find the place where 
it would sink into the ground, showing fertile soil. After many adventures 
and extensive searching, Ayar Manco and his siblings 
reached the Cuzco Valley, where the staff pierced the ground. After fighting off the fierce 
local native population, they founded their capital, and Ayar Manco became Manco Capac, 
the first Sapa Inca, or king of the Incas. Archaeological evidence suggests that the Incas first settled 
in this valley around 1200 CE. They remained a small kingdom until 1438, when they were nearly overrun 
by the neighboring Chanka tribe. The Inca king at this time, Viracocha, 
and his designated heir fled in fear, but one of his other sons remained and successfully rallied 
the city’s defenses. For his military skill, he became 
the ninth Inca ruler, assuming the name of Pachacuti, 
or "Cataclysm." Pachacuti expanded Inca rule 
throughout the Andes mountains, transforming the kingdom into 
an empire through extensive reforms. The empire’s territory was reorganized 
as Tahuantinsuyu, or "four quarters," with four divisions ruled 
by governors reporting to the king. Although the Inca had no writing, they used a complex system 
of knotted strings called quipu to record numbers 
and perhaps other information. A decimal-based bureaucracy 
enabled systematic and efficient taxation 
of the empire’s subjects. In return, the empire provided security, 
infrastructure, and sustenance, with great storehouses containing 
necessities to be used when needed. Great terraces and irrigation works 
were built and various crops were grown in 
at different altitudes to be transported all over the empire. And it was during Pachacuti’s reign that the famous estate 
of Machu Picchu was constructed. Pachacuti’s son Topa Inca continued 
the empire’s military expansion, and he eventually became ruler
in 1471 CE. By the end of his reign, the empire 
covered much of western South America. Topa’s son Huayna Capac 
succeeded him in 1493. But the new ruler’s distant military 
campaigns strained the social fabric. And in 1524, Huayna Capac 
was stricken by fever. Spanish conquistadors had arrived 
in the Caribbean some time before, bringing diseases to which 
the native peoples had no resistance. Millions died in the outbreak, including Huayna Capac
and his designated heir. The vacant throne ignited a civil war
between two of the surviving brothers, Atahualpa and Huascar, greatly weakening the empire. In 1532, after finally winning 
the Inca civil war, Atahualpa and his army 
encountered the European invaders. Although greatly outnumbered, Francisco Pizarro 
and his small group of conquistadors stunned the king’s much larger force 
with guns and horses, neither of which they had seen before. Atahualpa was taken captive 
and killed about a year later. The Spanish conquerors 
were awed by the capital of Cuzco. Pizarro described it as so beautiful that
“it would be remarkable even in Spain.” Though the capital had fallen and the native population had been
destroyed by civil war and disease, some Incas fell back to 
a new capital at Vilcabamba and resisted for the next 40 years. But by 1572, the Spaniards had destroyed 
all remaining resistance along with much of the Incas’ physical 
and cultural legacy. Thus, the great Inca empire fell 
even faster than it had risen.

Correct Option: A

It was the Western Hemisphere’s 
largest empire ever, with a population 
of nearly 10 million subjects. Over an area of more 
than 900,000 square kilometers, its people built massive 
administrative centers, temples, and extensive road 
and canal systems. They did so in an inhospitable, 
extreme terrain, all without the use of wheels, 
horses, iron, or even written language. Yet within 100 years of its rise 
in the fifteenth century, the Inca Empire would be no more. According to legend, the ancestors of the Inca rulers 
were created by the sun god Inti, and they emerged
from a cave called Tambo Toco. Leading four brothers 
and four sisters was Ayar Manco, who carried a golden staff 
with instructions to find the place where 
it would sink into the ground, showing fertile soil. After many adventures 
and extensive searching, Ayar Manco and his siblings 
reached the Cuzco Valley, where the staff pierced the ground. After fighting off the fierce 
local native population, they founded their capital, and Ayar Manco became Manco Capac, 
the first Sapa Inca, or king of the Incas. Archaeological evidence suggests that the Incas first settled 
in this valley around 1200 CE. They remained a small kingdom until 1438, when they were nearly overrun 
by the neighboring Chanka tribe. The Inca king at this time, Viracocha, 
and his designated heir fled in fear, but one of his other sons remained and successfully rallied 
the city’s defenses. For his military skill, he became 
the ninth Inca ruler, assuming the name of Pachacuti, 
or "Cataclysm." Pachacuti expanded Inca rule 
throughout the Andes mountains, transforming the kingdom into 
an empire through extensive reforms. The empire’s territory was reorganized 
as Tahuantinsuyu, or "four quarters," with four divisions ruled 
by governors reporting to the king. Although the Inca had no writing, they used a complex system 
of knotted strings called quipu to record numbers 
and perhaps other information. A decimal-based bureaucracy 
enabled systematic and efficient taxation 
of the empire’s subjects. In return, the empire provided security, 
infrastructure, and sustenance, with great storehouses containing 
necessities to be used when needed. Great terraces and irrigation works 
were built and various crops were grown in 
at different altitudes to be transported all over the empire. And it was during Pachacuti’s reign that the famous estate 
of Machu Picchu was constructed. Pachacuti’s son Topa Inca continued 
the empire’s military expansion, and he eventually became ruler
in 1471 CE. By the end of his reign, the empire 
covered much of western South America. Topa’s son Huayna Capac 
succeeded him in 1493. But the new ruler’s distant military 
campaigns strained the social fabric. And in 1524, Huayna Capac

between two of the surviving brothers, Atahualpa and Huascar, greatly weakening the empire. In 1532, after finally winning 
the Inca civil war, Atahualpa and his army

and his small group of conquistadors stunned the king’s much larger force 
with guns and horses, neither of which they had seen before. Atahualpa was taken captive 
and killed about a year later. The Spanish conquerors 
were awed by the capital of Cuzco. Pizarro described it as so beautiful that

a new capital at Vilcabamba and resisted for the next 40 years. But by 1572, the Spaniards had destroyed 
all remaining resistance along with much of the Incas’ physical

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
From sailors who were turned into pigs, nymphs that sprouted into trees, and a gaze that converted 
the beholder to stone, Greek mythology brims with shape-shifters. The powerful gods usually changed 
their own forms at will, but for mortals, the mutations 
were often unwanted. One such unnerving transformation 
befell the spinner Arachne. Arachne was the daughter 
of a tradesman who spent his days dying cloth 
the deepest shades of purple. She had a flair for spinning 
the finest threads, weaving them into flowing fabric, and creating magnificent tapestries. People flocked to watch her hands 
flying across her loom, as if thread sprung directly 
from her fingertips. But as praise for her work grew, 
so did her pride. Arachne could often be heard 
boasting about her skills, declaring that her talent surpassed 
anyone else’s—mortal or divine. She refused to see weaving 
as a gift from the gods. Rather, she flaunted it 
as her own personal genius. Unfortunately, the goddess of wisdom 
and crafts, Athena, overheard Arachne 
making these claims. Planning to teach 
the ungrateful girl a lesson, Athena disguised herself as an old woman
and stole amongst the mortals. She berated Arachne in public— how dare the weaver claim
herself greater than the gods? But Arachne only laughed, 
barely looking up from her loom. Provoked, the old woman threw off
her cloak to reveal her true form. If Arachne insisted on defaming the gods, Athena would challenge her 
to a contest directly. Masking her shock at the appearance 
of the grey-eyed goddess, Arachne accepted the challenge. Athena drew up her own glittering loom 
as a great crowd gathered to watch. The weavers began, 
eyes fixed and shuttles blurring. Athena conjured 
wisps of cloud from above and slender threads of grass 
from below in a spectacle of strength. She wove tremendous scenes 
that showed the power of the gods: Poseidon riding the waves, Zeus firing thunderbolts, and Apollo hurtling across the sky. In Athena’s splendid tapestry, 
the glory of the gods dwarfed mortal life. But Arachne had no interest 
in boosting godly egos. Her tapestry showed the gods
abusing their power: squabbling amongst themselves, drinking and bragging, and meddling in the lives of mortals. She represented Zeus as a philanderer,
transfiguring himself to ensnare women: a swan for Leda, a bull for Europa, a shower of gold for Danae. Arachne then turned
to the misdemeanors of other gods, from Pluto’s abduction of Persephone to Bacchus’s wild pursuit of Erigone. Even though she cast the gods 
in the most unflattering light, Arachne’s work shone 
with her dazzling skill. Her tapestry was almost alive, filled with movement 
and lustrous colors that winked triumphantly. When Athena saw Arachne's undeniably
better and flagrantly subversive work, she flew into a rage 
and turned on the human weaver. Arachne’s glee dimmed as she felt her body
shrinking and contorting. Her fingers waved wildly 
as her arms stuck to her sides, and black hair
sprouted all over her body. The goddess left Arachne with a single 
spool of thread unfurling from her belly, a slim reminder of her human talent. For challenging the assumption
that the gods were untouchable, Athena had shrunk her adversary 
into the first spider. To this day, Arachne and her children spin
out her penance— or is it undaunted persistence?— in the shadows of giants.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Arachne was ______.
Options: A. A noblewoman, B. An apprentice, C. A slave, D. A self-taught weaver
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was Arachne's occupation, and what was she particularly skilled at? Options: A. She was a sailor, skilled at navigation., B. She was a weaver, skilled at creating magnificent tapestries., C. She was a tradeswoman, skilled at dying cloth., D. She was a goddess, skilled at shape-shifting. Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the reason behind Athena's decision to disguise herself as an old woman and confront Arachne? Options: A. Athena wanted to learn from Arachne's exceptional weaving skills., B. Athena was offended by Arachne's claims that her talent surpassed that of the gods., C. Athena wanted to test Arachne's knowledge of Greek mythology., D. Athena was seeking a mortal friend. Correct Option: B
Question 3: If you were in Arachne's position, how would you have responded to Athena's challenge to a weaving contest? Explain your reasoning. Options: A. I would have apologized and retreated, acknowledging Athena's divine authority., B. I would have accepted the challenge, confident in my skills and eager to prove myself., C. I would have asked for more information about the contest rules and judging criteria., D. I would have refused to participate, citing the unfair advantage of a goddess. Correct Option: B
Question 4: Analyze the themes presented in the tapestries created by Athena and Arachne. What do they reveal about their creators' perspectives on the gods? Options: A. Athena's tapestry showed the power of the gods, while Arachne's tapestry depicted their weaknesses., B. Athena's tapestry highlighted the gods' flaws, while Arachne's tapestry celebrated their greatness., C. Both tapestries presented a neutral, balanced view of the gods., D. The tapestries were not meant to convey any themes or messages. Correct Option: A
Question 5: What was the outcome of the weaving contest between Athena and Arachne? Options: A. Athena's tapestry was deemed superior, and Arachne was praised for her efforts., B. Arachne's tapestry was considered better, but Athena was declared the winner due to her divine status., C. The contest ended in a tie, with both participants showcasing exceptional skills., D. Arachne's tapestry was deemed superior, and Athena transformed her into a spider as punishment. Correct Option: D
Question 6: Evaluate the character of Arachne. Was she justified in her claims of superiority, or did she demonstrate hubris? Options: A. Arachne was justified in her claims, as her skills were truly exceptional., B. Arachne demonstrated hubris, as she failed to acknowledge the role of the gods in her talents., C. Arachne was neither justified nor hubristic; she was simply confident in her abilities., D. Arachne's character is irrelevant to the story. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the significance of the spool of thread unfurling from Arachne's belly after her transformation into a spider? Options: A. It symbolized her lost talent and connection to her human past., B. It represented her newfound ability to spin webs., C. It served as a reminder of Athena's power and authority., D. It was a mere coincidence with no deeper meaning. Correct Option: A
Question 8: Create a title for the story of Arachne and Athena. What themes or messages do you think the title should convey? Options: A. "The Weaver's Pride", B. "Athena's Wrath", C. "The Spider's Gift", D. "Mortal Ambition vs. Divine Authority" Correct Option: D
Question 9: Compare and contrast the characters of Athena and Arachne. What similarities and differences do they exhibit? Options: A. Both Athena and Arachne are skilled weavers, but Athena is divine, while Arachne is mortal., B. Athena is depicted as wise and just, while Arachne is portrayed as arrogant and rebellious., C. Both characters demonstrate exceptional intelligence and creativity., D. Athena and Arachne share no similarities, as they are from different worlds. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What message do you think the story of Arachne and Athena conveys about the relationship between mortals and gods in Greek mythology? Options: A. The story highlights the importance of respecting and worshiping the gods., B. The story suggests that mortals can challenge the gods and emerge victorious., C. The story emphasizes the capricious nature of the gods and the dangers of hubris., D. The story has no deeper meaning or message. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I have identified the most similar generated MCQ as:

**Question 1: What was Arachne's occupation, and what was she particularly skilled at?**

Although this question does not directly ask about Arachne's social status or background, it does provide information about her occupation and skills, which can be inferred to be related to her being a "self-taught weaver" (the correct answer in the ground truth MCQ).

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
From sailors who were turned into pigs, nymphs that sprouted into trees, and a gaze that converted 
the beholder to stone, Greek mythology brims with shape-shifters. The powerful gods usually changed 
their own forms at will, but for mortals, the mutations 
were often unwanted. One such unnerving transformation 
befell the spinner Arachne. Arachne was the daughter 
of a tradesman who spent his days dying cloth 
the deepest shades of purple. She had a flair for spinning 
the finest threads, weaving them into flowing fabric, and creating magnificent tapestries. People flocked to watch her hands 
flying across her loom, as if thread sprung directly 
from her fingertips. But as praise for her work grew, 
so did her pride. Arachne could often be heard 
boasting about her skills, declaring that her talent surpassed 
anyone else’s—mortal or divine. She refused to see weaving 
as a gift from the gods. Rather, she flaunted it 
as her own personal genius. Unfortunately, the goddess of wisdom 
and crafts, Athena, overheard Arachne 
making these claims. Planning to teach 
the ungrateful girl a lesson, Athena disguised herself as an old woman
and stole amongst the mortals. She berated Arachne in public— how dare the weaver claim
herself greater than the gods? But Arachne only laughed, 
barely looking up from her loom. Provoked, the old woman threw off
her cloak to reveal her true form. If Arachne insisted on defaming the gods, Athena would challenge her 
to a contest directly. Masking her shock at the appearance 
of the grey-eyed goddess, Arachne accepted the challenge. Athena drew up her own glittering loom 
as a great crowd gathered to watch. The weavers began, 
eyes fixed and shuttles blurring. Athena conjured 
wisps of cloud from above and slender threads of grass 
from below in a spectacle of strength. She wove tremendous scenes 
that showed the power of the gods: Poseidon riding the waves, Zeus firing thunderbolts, and Apollo hurtling across the sky. In Athena’s splendid tapestry, 
the glory of the gods dwarfed mortal life. But Arachne had no interest 
in boosting godly egos. Her tapestry showed the gods
abusing their power: squabbling amongst themselves, drinking and bragging, and meddling in the lives of mortals. She represented Zeus as a philanderer,
transfiguring himself to ensnare women: a swan for Leda, a bull for Europa, a shower of gold for Danae. Arachne then turned
to the misdemeanors of other gods, from Pluto’s abduction of Persephone to Bacchus’s wild pursuit of Erigone. Even though she cast the gods 
in the most unflattering light, Arachne’s work shone 
with her dazzling skill. Her tapestry was almost alive, filled with movement 
and lustrous colors that winked triumphantly. When Athena saw Arachne's undeniably
better and flagrantly subversive work, she flew into a rage 
and turned on the human weaver. Arachne’s glee dimmed as she felt her body
shrinking and contorting. Her fingers waved wildly 
as her arms stuck to her sides, and black hair
sprouted all over her body. The goddess left Arachne with a single 
spool of thread unfurling from her belly, a slim reminder of her human talent. For challenging the assumption
that the gods were untouchable, Athena had shrunk her adversary 
into the first spider. To this day, Arachne and her children spin
out her penance— or is it undaunted persistence?— in the shadows of giants.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Athena was the goddess of ______.
Options: A. Farming, B. Fabric, C. Wisdom, D. Love
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was Arachne's occupation, and what was she particularly skilled at? Options: A. She was a sailor, skilled at navigation., B. She was a weaver, skilled at creating magnificent tapestries., C. She was a tradeswoman, skilled at dying cloth., D. She was a goddess, skilled at shape-shifting. Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the reason behind Athena's decision to disguise herself as an old woman and confront Arachne? Options: A. Athena wanted to learn from Arachne's exceptional weaving skills., B. Athena was offended by Arachne's claims that her talent surpassed that of the gods., C. Athena wanted to test Arachne's knowledge of Greek mythology., D. Athena was seeking a mortal friend. Correct Option: B
Question 3: If you were in Arachne's position, how would you have responded to Athena's challenge to a weaving contest? Explain your reasoning. Options: A. I would have apologized and retreated, acknowledging Athena's divine authority., B. I would have accepted the challenge, confident in my skills and eager to prove myself., C. I would have asked for more information about the contest rules and judging criteria., D. I would have refused to participate, citing the unfair advantage of a goddess. Correct Option: B
Question 4: Analyze the themes presented in the tapestries created by Athena and Arachne. What do they reveal about their creators' perspectives on the gods? Options: A. Athena's tapestry showed the power of the gods, while Arachne's tapestry depicted their weaknesses., B. Athena's tapestry highlighted the gods' flaws, while Arachne's tapestry celebrated their greatness., C. Both tapestries presented a neutral, balanced view of the gods., D. The tapestries were not meant to convey any themes or messages. Correct Option: A
Question 5: What was the outcome of the weaving contest between Athena and Arachne? Options: A. Athena's tapestry was deemed superior, and Arachne was praised for her efforts., B. Arachne's tapestry was considered better, but Athena was declared the winner due to her divine status., C. The contest ended in a tie, with both participants showcasing exceptional skills., D. Arachne's tapestry was deemed superior, and Athena transformed her into a spider as punishment. Correct Option: D
Question 6: Evaluate the character of Arachne. Was she justified in her claims of superiority, or did she demonstrate hubris? Options: A. Arachne was justified in her claims, as her skills were truly exceptional., B. Arachne demonstrated hubris, as she failed to acknowledge the role of the gods in her talents., C. Arachne was neither justified nor hubristic; she was simply confident in her abilities., D. Arachne's character is irrelevant to the story. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the significance of the spool of thread unfurling from Arachne's belly after her transformation into a spider? Options: A. It symbolized her lost talent and connection to her human past., B. It represented her newfound ability to spin webs., C. It served as a reminder of Athena's power and authority., D. It was a mere coincidence with no deeper meaning. Correct Option: A
Question 8: Create a title for the story of Arachne and Athena. What themes or messages do you think the title should convey? Options: A. "The Weaver's Pride", B. "Athena's Wrath", C. "The Spider's Gift", D. "Mortal Ambition vs. Divine Authority" Correct Option: D
Question 9: Compare and contrast the characters of Athena and Arachne. What similarities and differences do they exhibit? Options: A. Both Athena and Arachne are skilled weavers, but Athena is divine, while Arachne is mortal., B. Athena is depicted as wise and just, while Arachne is portrayed as arrogant and rebellious., C. Both characters demonstrate exceptional intelligence and creativity., D. Athena and Arachne share no similarities, as they are from different worlds. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What message do you think the story of Arachne and Athena conveys about the relationship between mortals and gods in Greek mythology? Options: A. The story highlights the importance of respecting and worshiping the gods., B. The story suggests that mortals can challenge the gods and emerge victorious., C. The story emphasizes the capricious nature of the gods and the dangers of hubris., D. The story has no deeper meaning or message. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

Both Athena and Arachne are skilled weavers, but Athena is divine, while Arachne is mortal., B. Athena is depicted as wise and just, while Arachne is portrayed as arrogant and rebellious., C. Both characters demonstrate exceptional intelligence and creativity., D. Athena and Arachne share no similarities, as they are from different worlds. Correct Option: A**

However, this question does not directly ask about Athena's domain. A more relevant question would be one that directly inquires about Athena's characteristics or roles.

**Transcript**:
From sailors who were turned into pigs, nymphs that sprouted into trees, and a gaze that converted 
the beholder to stone, Greek mythology brims with shape-shifters. The powerful gods usually changed 
their own forms at will, but for mortals, the mutations 
were often unwanted. One such unnerving transformation 
befell the spinner Arachne. Arachne was the daughter 
of a tradesman who spent his days dying cloth 
the deepest shades of purple. She had a flair for spinning 
the finest threads, weaving them into flowing fabric, and creating magnificent tapestries. People flocked to watch her hands 
flying across her loom, as if thread sprung directly 
from her fingertips. But as praise for her work grew, 
so did her pride. Arachne could often be heard 
boasting about her skills, declaring that her talent surpassed 
anyone else’s—mortal or divine. She refused to see weaving 
as a gift from the gods. Rather, she flaunted it 
as her own personal genius. Unfortunately, the goddess of wisdom 
and crafts, Athena, overheard Arachne 
making these claims. Planning to teach 
the ungrateful girl a lesson, Athena disguised herself as an old woman
and stole amongst the mortals. She berated Arachne in public— how dare the weaver claim
herself greater than the gods? But Arachne only laughed, 
barely looking up from her loom. Provoked, the old woman threw off
her cloak to reveal her true form. If Arachne insisted on defaming the gods, Athena would challenge her 
to a contest directly. Masking her shock at the appearance 
of the grey-eyed goddess, Arachne accepted the challenge. Athena drew up her own glittering loom 
as a great crowd gathered to watch. The weavers began, 
eyes fixed and shuttles blurring. Athena conjured 
wisps of cloud from above and slender threads of grass 
from below in a spectacle of strength. She wove tremendous scenes 
that showed the power of the gods: Poseidon riding the waves, Zeus firing thunderbolts, and Apollo hurtling across the sky. In Athena’s splendid tapestry, 
the glory of the gods dwarfed mortal life. But Arachne had no interest 
in boosting godly egos. Her tapestry showed the gods
abusing their power: squabbling amongst themselves, drinking and bragging, and meddling in the lives of mortals. She represented Zeus as a philanderer,
transfiguring himself to ensnare women: a swan for Leda, a bull for Europa, a shower of gold for Danae. Arachne then turned
to the misdemeanors of other gods, from Pluto’s abduction of Persephone to Bacchus’s wild pursuit of Erigone. Even though she cast the gods 
in the most unflattering light, Arachne’s work shone 
with her dazzling skill. Her tapestry was almost alive, filled with movement 
and lustrous colors that winked triumphantly. When Athena saw Arachne's undeniably
better and flagrantly subversive work, she flew into a rage 
and turned on the human weaver. Arachne’s glee dimmed as she felt her body
shrinking and contorting. Her fingers waved wildly 
as her arms stuck to her sides, and black hair
sprouted all over her body. The goddess left Arachne with a single 
spool of thread unfurling from her belly, a slim reminder of her human talent. For challenging the assumption
that the gods were untouchable, Athena had shrunk her adversary 
into the first spider. To this day, Arachne and her children spin
out her penance— or is it undaunted persistence?— in the shadows of giants.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Athena disguised herself and stole amongst the mortals in order to ______.
Options: A. Admire Arachne’s work anonymously, B. Hear Arachne’s boasting for herself, C. See if Arachne was a better weaver than she was, D. Steal Arachne’s talent for herself, E. See if Arachne was a better weaver than she was and steal Arachne’s talent for herself
Correct Option: E

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
From sailors who were turned into pigs, nymphs that sprouted into trees, and a gaze that converted 
the beholder to stone, Greek mythology brims with shape-shifters. The powerful gods usually changed 
their own forms at will, but for mortals, the mutations 
were often unwanted. One such unnerving transformation 
befell the spinner Arachne. Arachne was the daughter 
of a tradesman who spent his days dying cloth 
the deepest shades of purple. She had a flair for spinning 
the finest threads, weaving them into flowing fabric, and creating magnificent tapestries. People flocked to watch her hands 
flying across her loom, as if thread sprung directly 
from her fingertips. But as praise for her work grew, 
so did her pride. Arachne could often be heard 
boasting about her skills, declaring that her talent surpassed 
anyone else’s—mortal or divine. She refused to see weaving 
as a gift from the gods. Rather, she flaunted it 
as her own personal genius. Unfortunately, the goddess of wisdom 
and crafts, Athena, overheard Arachne 
making these claims. Planning to teach 
the ungrateful girl a lesson, Athena disguised herself as an old woman
and stole amongst the mortals. She berated Arachne in public— how dare the weaver claim
herself greater than the gods? But Arachne only laughed, 
barely looking up from her loom. Provoked, the old woman threw off
her cloak to reveal her true form. If Arachne insisted on defaming the gods, Athena would challenge her 
to a contest directly. Masking her shock at the appearance 
of the grey-eyed goddess, Arachne accepted the challenge. Athena drew up her own glittering loom 
as a great crowd gathered to watch. The weavers began, 
eyes fixed and shuttles blurring. Athena conjured 
wisps of cloud from above and slender threads of grass 
from below in a spectacle of strength. She wove tremendous scenes 
that showed the power of the gods: Poseidon riding the waves, Zeus firing thunderbolts, and Apollo hurtling across the sky. In Athena’s splendid tapestry, 
the glory of the gods dwarfed mortal life. But Arachne had no interest 
in boosting godly egos. Her tapestry showed the gods
abusing their power: squabbling amongst themselves, drinking and bragging, and meddling in the lives of mortals. She represented Zeus as a philanderer,
transfiguring himself to ensnare women: a swan for Leda, a bull for Europa, a shower of gold for Danae. Arachne then turned
to the misdemeanors of other gods, from Pluto’s abduction of Persephone to Bacchus’s wild pursuit of Erigone. Even though she cast the gods 
in the most unflattering light, Arachne’s work shone 
with her dazzling skill. Her tapestry was almost alive, filled with movement 
and lustrous colors that winked triumphantly. When Athena saw Arachne's undeniably
better and flagrantly subversive work, she flew into a rage 
and turned on the human weaver. Arachne’s glee dimmed as she felt her body
shrinking and contorting. Her fingers waved wildly 
as her arms stuck to her sides, and black hair
sprouted all over her body. The goddess left Arachne with a single 
spool of thread unfurling from her belly, a slim reminder of her human talent. For challenging the assumption
that the gods were untouchable, Athena had shrunk her adversary 
into the first spider. To this day, Arachne and her children spin
out her penance— or is it undaunted persistence?— in the shadows of giants.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Arachne’s depictions of Zeus showed him ______.
Options: A. Hurling thunderbolts, B. Seducing women, C. Ruling with justice, D. Going to War
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
From sailors who were turned into pigs, nymphs that sprouted into trees, and a gaze that converted 
the beholder to stone, Greek mythology brims with shape-shifters. The powerful gods usually changed 
their own forms at will, but for mortals, the mutations 
were often unwanted. One such unnerving transformation 
befell the spinner Arachne. Arachne was the daughter 
of a tradesman who spent his days dying cloth 
the deepest shades of purple. She had a flair for spinning 
the finest threads, weaving them into flowing fabric, and creating magnificent tapestries. People flocked to watch her hands 
flying across her loom, as if thread sprung directly 
from her fingertips. But as praise for her work grew, 
so did her pride. Arachne could often be heard 
boasting about her skills, declaring that her talent surpassed 
anyone else’s—mortal or divine. She refused to see weaving 
as a gift from the gods. Rather, she flaunted it 
as her own personal genius. Unfortunately, the goddess of wisdom 
and crafts, Athena, overheard Arachne 
making these claims. Planning to teach 
the ungrateful girl a lesson, Athena disguised herself as an old woman
and stole amongst the mortals. She berated Arachne in public— how dare the weaver claim
herself greater than the gods? But Arachne only laughed, 
barely looking up from her loom. Provoked, the old woman threw off
her cloak to reveal her true form. If Arachne insisted on defaming the gods, Athena would challenge her 
to a contest directly. Masking her shock at the appearance 
of the grey-eyed goddess, Arachne accepted the challenge. Athena drew up her own glittering loom 
as a great crowd gathered to watch. The weavers began, 
eyes fixed and shuttles blurring. Athena conjured 
wisps of cloud from above and slender threads of grass 
from below in a spectacle of strength. She wove tremendous scenes 
that showed the power of the gods: Poseidon riding the waves, Zeus firing thunderbolts, and Apollo hurtling across the sky. In Athena’s splendid tapestry, 
the glory of the gods dwarfed mortal life. But Arachne had no interest 
in boosting godly egos. Her tapestry showed the gods
abusing their power: squabbling amongst themselves, drinking and bragging, and meddling in the lives of mortals. She represented Zeus as a philanderer,
transfiguring himself to ensnare women: a swan for Leda, a bull for Europa, a shower of gold for Danae. Arachne then turned
to the misdemeanors of other gods, from Pluto’s abduction of Persephone to Bacchus’s wild pursuit of Erigone. Even though she cast the gods 
in the most unflattering light, Arachne’s work shone 
with her dazzling skill. Her tapestry was almost alive, filled with movement 
and lustrous colors that winked triumphantly. When Athena saw Arachne's undeniably
better and flagrantly subversive work, she flew into a rage 
and turned on the human weaver. Arachne’s glee dimmed as she felt her body
shrinking and contorting. Her fingers waved wildly 
as her arms stuck to her sides, and black hair
sprouted all over her body. The goddess left Arachne with a single 
spool of thread unfurling from her belly, a slim reminder of her human talent. For challenging the assumption
that the gods were untouchable, Athena had shrunk her adversary 
into the first spider. To this day, Arachne and her children spin
out her penance— or is it undaunted persistence?— in the shadows of giants.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Arachne was punished for ______.
Options: A. Her talent, B. Her defiance, C. Her skill, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was Arachne's occupation, and what was she particularly skilled at? Options: A. She was a sailor, skilled at navigation., B. She was a weaver, skilled at creating magnificent tapestries., C. She was a tradeswoman, skilled at dying cloth., D. She was a goddess, skilled at shape-shifting. Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the reason behind Athena's decision to disguise herself as an old woman and confront Arachne? Options: A. Athena wanted to learn from Arachne's exceptional weaving skills., B. Athena was offended by Arachne's claims that her talent surpassed that of the gods., C. Athena wanted to test Arachne's knowledge of Greek mythology., D. Athena was seeking a mortal friend. Correct Option: B
Question 3: If you were in Arachne's position, how would you have responded to Athena's challenge to a weaving contest? Explain your reasoning. Options: A. I would have apologized and retreated, acknowledging Athena's divine authority., B. I would have accepted the challenge, confident in my skills and eager to prove myself., C. I would have asked for more information about the contest rules and judging criteria., D. I would have refused to participate, citing the unfair advantage of a goddess. Correct Option: B
Question 4: Analyze the themes presented in the tapestries created by Athena and Arachne. What do they reveal about their creators' perspectives on the gods? Options: A. Athena's tapestry showed the power of the gods, while Arachne's tapestry depicted their weaknesses., B. Athena's tapestry highlighted the gods' flaws, while Arachne's tapestry celebrated their greatness., C. Both tapestries presented a neutral, balanced view of the gods., D. The tapestries were not meant to convey any themes or messages. Correct Option: A

Arachne's tapestry was considered better, but Athena was declared the winner due to her divine status., C. The contest ended in a tie, with both participants showcasing exceptional skills., D. Arachne's tapestry was deemed superior, and Athena transformed her into a spider as punishment. Correct Option: D

Arachne was justified in her claims, as her skills were truly exceptional., B. Arachne demonstrated hubris, as she failed to acknowledge the role of the gods in her talents., C. Arachne was neither justified nor hubristic; she was simply confident in her abilities., D. Arachne's character is irrelevant to the story. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the significance of the spool of thread unfurling from Arachne's belly after her transformation into a spider? Options: A. It symbolized her lost talent and connection to her human past., B. It represented her newfound ability to spin webs., C. It served as a reminder of Athena's power and authority., D. It was a mere coincidence with no deeper meaning. Correct Option: A

Question 9: Compare and contrast the characters of Athena and Arachne. What similarities and differences do they exhibit? Options: A. Both Athena and Arachne are skilled weavers, but Athena is divine, while Arachne is mortal., B. Athena is depicted as wise and just, while Arachne is portrayed as arrogant and rebellious., C. Both characters demonstrate exceptional intelligence and creativity., D. Athena and Arachne share no similarities, as they are from different worlds. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What message do you think the story of Arachne and Athena conveys about the relationship between mortals and gods in Greek mythology? Options: A. The story highlights the importance of respecting and worshiping the gods., B. The story suggests that mortals can challenge the gods and emerge victorious., C. The story emphasizes the capricious nature of the gods and the dangers of hubris., D. The story has no deeper meaning or message. Correct Option: C

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.
